text: this is the RACI anderson manufacturing
plant in LaGrange Georgia it is named
for this man my name is Ray Anderson and
this carpet rolling off the
manufacturing line here may be the
greenest carpet you have ever seen it
was a spear in the chest it was 13 years
ago Anderson the 72 year old chairman of
interface corporation was to deliver a
speech about his company's environmental
efforts he says it woke him up to a
startling reality when I found out in
1994 I was flabbergasted the industrial
system is digging up the earth
converting it to products that have very
short lives and end up in landfills and
incinerators very quickly it is a waste
making machine and it must be changed
unusual words from a man who built a
small empire manufacturing a product
which added millions of tons of waste to
landfills every year with sales of 1.1
billion dollars a year interface is
today the world's largest manufacturer
of modular carpet also known as carpet
tile it's not the most glamorous product
but it is a ubiquitous one the carpet
business has been dirty the raw
materials are mostly petroleum products
manufacturing consumes lots of energy
and the solid waste that carpet
generates mostly go straight to landfill
carpet in a landfill will last 20,000
years reducing this waste is how ray
Anderson began his crusade we redefined
waste in our company as any cost that
goes into our products it does not
deliver value to
customers that means scrapped and it
means off quality defective product and
it means anything you don't do right the
first time what they discovered was a
surprise
we found ten percent of the sales dollar
was going down the drain as waste so we
set out to eliminate waste in nature
there's no waste so we took a model from
nature one of the company's newest and
most innovative efforts to reduce waste
can be seen here this massive recycling
machine affectionately called cool blue
was engineered specifically for
interface this is Stuart Jones the
company's vice president for sustainable
development this process takes waste
carpet and other waste materials that
would have been land filled or
incinerated and it utilizes them to make
a new carpet backing gives it another
life and a long life at that the company
says that as a result of these efforts
its global contribution to landfills has
been reduced 80 percent but serious
obstacles remain the most difficult one
remaining has to do with the nylon
face of our country you know either we
have to learn to recycle nylon or our
suppliers have to learn to recycle now
on all we have to find a substitute one
way or the other we will solve that
problem and it remains the biggest
technical challenge other signs of the
company's green practices can be seen
everywhere around the factory floor in
fact on the factory floor here unused
yarn is brought to specially designed
machines where it is rewound to be
reused
cardboard boxes are recycled extensively
low-energy bulbs illuminate the floor
and skylights have been cut into the
roof to allow in natural light the
process heat for our backing lines here
in the plant come from or supplied by
methane from our local landfill the
company says it has reduced its
consumption of fossil fuels by 45%
partly through solar power and higher
efficiencies but also by tapping
unorthodox local sources landfill was
capped and converted to a bioreactor so
the methane that's produced as the
garbage decomposes is then captured and
pumped here piped here to the plant
where it comes in to our boiler systems
and we burn that for our processing
employees have bought into mr.
Anderson's vision not just because they
receive financial incentives for meeting
green goals but also because they
embrace the message is very personal it
even affects at hall's what I do by
recycling taking lifted from the layer
and put it lift it back out in the
landfill mr. Anderson says his company's
conservation efforts have added hundreds
of millions of dollars to its bottom
line and that other companies can see
similar benefits all the time that
there's this trade-off between the
environment and the economy we've proven
that to be false trade off our products
the best they've never been a cost down
not now mr. Anderson has given up the
day-to-day in the factory and spends
most of his time on the road
evangelizing sustainable corporate
practices but he remains an advocate for
business and for the role business can
play in improving the environment that
is large enough powerful enough
pervasive enough wealthy enough and
influential enough to really lead
humankind in a different direction you
out of that and miss that we have
created for ourselves and that is the
institution of business and industry
